title: The Organist's Reverence
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy, the church organist, was a fixture. For fifty years, his nimble fingers danced across the keys, filling the sanctuary with glorious music that lifted hearts to the heavens. But time, as it always does, had taken its toll. His hands, once so sure, now trembled, and his playing, though still beautiful, was often punctuated by missed notes and faltering rhythms. Some whispered it was time for him to step aside, make way for a younger, more technically proficient musician. The whispers reached the ears of the new pastor, who was eager to modernize the service. 

One Sunday, a renowned concert pianist visited the church. His performance was flawless, a dazzling display of skill and artistry. Afterward, the pastor, beaming, introduced him to Mr. Abernathy, suggesting they might learn from one another. The pianist, though polite, couldn't hide a hint of condescension. He offered a few pointers on technique, subtly implying that Mr. Abernathy's style was outdated. Mr. Abernathy listened quietly, his eyes twinkling behind his spectacles. 

The following Sunday, Mr. Abernathy was back at the organ. He didn't try to imitate the pianist's flashiness. Instead, he played with a simple, heartfelt reverence. Each note was a prayer, each chord a testament to God's enduring grace. The music wasn't perfect, but it was profound. As the congregation sang along, tears welled in many eyes. It wasn't just the music they were hearing; it was the lifetime of devotion, the unwavering faithfulness, poured out through the hands of a humble servant. 

That day, the pastor realized that true reverence wasn't about technical perfection, but about a deep, abiding love for God expressed through every action, every note, every moment of service. Mr. Abernathy’s imperfect playing was a far greater offering than any flawless performance could ever be, because it came from a place of profound reverence.
image_description: A close-up of old, worn hands gently resting on the keys of a vintage pipe organ.
insights: This story illustrates that reverence goes beyond outward displays of piety or flawless execution. It’s about the inner attitude of the heart, the sincere and humble acknowledgment of God's presence and worth. Psalm 95:6 reminds us, 'Oh come, let us worship and bow down; let us kneel before the Lord, our Maker!' This verse calls us not just to perform acts of worship, but to approach God with a posture of humility and awe.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I've prioritized perfection over reverence, skill over sincerity. Help me to approach You with a humble and grateful heart, recognizing Your majesty and grace in all that I do. Teach me to express my love and devotion not just through words and actions, but through a spirit of reverence that permeates every aspect of my life. In Jesus’ name, Amen.
reflection: How can you cultivate a greater sense of reverence in your daily life? Are there areas where you’ve become complacent or focused on outward appearances rather than inward devotion? What small steps can you take to express your love and gratitude to God more sincerely?
